intro: Acacia plectocarpa subsp. tanumbirinensis, commonly known as the Tanumbirinensis wattle, is a shrub or small tree native to northern Australia. It is characterized by its phyllodes, which are flattened, leaf-like structures that are typically narrow and linear. The plant produces yellow flowers in dense, globular clusters, which are a notable feature during the flowering season. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. The subspecies is distinguished by its specific geographic distribution and morphological traits that set it apart from other acacia species.
taxonomy_art_desc: Acacia plectocarpa subsp. tanumbirinensis belongs to the kingdom Plantae. Its phylum is Streptophyta, which includes land plants and is characterized by the presence of true roots, stems, and leaves. Its class is Equisetopsida, which encompasses ferns and their allies, including horsetails and some early land plants. Its subclass is Magnoliidae, a group of flowering plants that includes many economically important species such as roses and magnolias. Its order is Fabales, which consists of flowering plants that typically have flowers with five petals and are often legumes. Its family is Fabaceae, known as the legume or pea family, characterized by pod fruits and nitrogen-fixing capabilities. Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees commonly found in arid and tropical regions, known for their distinctive acorn-like seed pods. Its species is Acacia plectocarpa, a specific type of acacia that has a subspecies tanumbirinensis, which is adapted to particular environmental conditions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia plectocarpa subsp. tanumbirinensis is primarily native to the Northern Territory and Queensland of Australia. This subspecies is typically found in arid and semi-arid regions within these areas. It thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is commonly associated with dry woodlands and shrublands. The plant is well adapted to the harsh environmental conditions of its native range. Its distribution is limited to specific ecological zones within the mentioned regions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia plectocarpa subsp. tanumbirinensis was mainly introduced to areas with well-drained soils and a tropical to subtropical climate. It thrives in regions with moderate rainfall and full sun exposure. This subspecies is commonly found in coastal and inland regions of northern Australia. It is often used for soil stabilization and as a source of timber. Its introduction has had both ecological and economic impacts on the regions where it is established.
